options: A) The frequency at which the circuit resonates
B) The (v, i) pair at which the circuit operates under DC excitation
C) The maximum power delivered by the source
D) The Thevenin equivalent resistance of the circuit
questions.correctAnswer: B) The (v, i) pair at which the circuit operates under DC excitation
questions.explanation: The DC operating point is the specific voltage-current pair that satisfies all circuit constraints (KCL, KVL, and element equations) simultaneously under DC conditions.

questions.prompt: A circuit with only linear passive resistors and a single DC source has:
questions.explanation: Linear resistor characteristics are straight lines. The system of linear equations has a unique solution, guaranteeing exactly one operating point.

questions.prompt: In the back-to-back one-port model, the operating points correspond to:
options: A) The maxima of the power curve
B) The zeros of the voltage function
C) The intersections of the two sub-circuit v-i characteristics
D) The points where current is zero
questions.correctAnswer: C) The intersections of the two sub-circuit v-i characteristics
questions.explanation: KVL forces va = vb and KCL forces ia = -ib. The points satisfying both constraints are precisely the intersections of the two v-i curves (with appropriate sign convention).

questions.prompt: The load line for a DC source Eb in series with resistor Rb has voltage-axis intercept at:
questions.explanation: Setting i = 0 in the load-line equation i = (Eb - v)/Rb gives v = Eb. The load line crosses the voltage axis at v = Eb.

questions.prompt: The load line for Eb = 3V and Rb = 1 ohm has current-axis intercept at:
questions.explanation: Setting v = 0 in i = (Eb - v)/Rb gives i = Eb/Rb = 3/1 = 3 A.

questions.prompt: A device has characteristic i = 4v^2. The load line is i = 8 - 4v. How many operating points exist?
questions.explanation: Setting 4v^2 = 8 - 4v gives 4v^2 + 4v - 8 = 0, i.e., v^2 + v - 2 = 0. The discriminant is 1 + 8 = 9 > 0, so there are two real solutions: v = 1 and v = -2.

questions.prompt: For the device i = 4v^2 with load line i = 8 - 4v, the operating point at v = 1V has current:
questions.explanation: Substituting v = 1 into the device equation: i = 4(1)^2 = 4 A. Alternatively, from the load line: i = 8 - 4(1) = 4 A. Both give 4 A.

questions.prompt: If the device curve and load line do not intersect, the circuit:
options: B) Has infinitely many operating points
C) Has no DC operating point
questions.correctAnswer: C) Has no DC operating point
questions.explanation: No intersection means no (v, i) pair satisfies both the device equation and the load-line equation simultaneously. The circuit has no valid DC operating point under the given model.

questions.prompt: In the Newton-Raphson method, the update rule is:
questions.explanation: Newton-Raphson updates the estimate by subtracting the ratio f(x_n)/f'(x_n). This is derived from approximating f by its tangent line at x_n and finding the root of that tangent line.
